(3) Macroevolutionary ratchet: Certain evolutionary transitions may be effectively irreversible if returning to the ancestral state requires multiple simultaneous changes ("Dollo's law" applied to complex trait suites). (4) Alternative explanation: Bird-pollinated lineages may persist longer (lower extinction rates) or diversify faster, biasing observed patterns toward bird-pollinated tips. (5) This pattern (asymmetric transitions) has been documented in multiple families including Penstemon, Iochroma, and Ruellia.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the endosperm of an angiosperm seed?
options: It is diploid tissue derived from the maternal sporophyte
It is triploid tissue resulting from fusion of one sperm with two polar nuclei
It is haploid tissue derived from the female gametophyte
It is tetraploid tissue resulting from fusion of both sperm with the central cell
questions.explanation: Angiosperm endosperm is typically triploid (3n), formed by the fusion of one haploid sperm cell (n) with the diploid central cell (2n) of the embryo sac. The central cell usually contains two polar nuclei (each n) that fuse before or during fertilization to form a diploid nucleus, which then fuses with the sperm to produce a triploid endosperm nucleus. This endosperm divides mitotically to form the nutritive tissue that supports embryo development and, in many species, early seedling growth. In some species (e.g., coconut), endosperm persists in the mature seed (albuminous seeds), while in others (e.g., beans, peas), endosperm is absorbed by developing cotyledons during seed maturation (exalbuminous seeds). The triploid nature of endosperm creates an interesting genetic asymmetry with consequences for parent-offspring conflict and genomic imprinting.

questions.question: To test whether a specific angiosperm-insect pollination mutualism is obligate (neither partner can reproduce without the other) versus facultative, the most informative experiment is:
options: Observe pollinator behavior at flowers using video recording
Sequence the genomes of both the plant and insect to look for coevolved genes
Exclude the suspected pollinator and measure seed set compared to open-pollinated controls, then test whether the insect can obtain equivalent nutrition from other flower species
Measure nectar sugar concentration and compare with the insect's dietary requirements
questions.explanation: Distinguishing obligate from facultative mutualism requires demonstrating that each partner cannot succeed without the other. The two-part experiment described in option B tests both sides: (1) Pollinator exclusion experiments (using mesh cages that exclude the specific pollinator but allow other potential pollinators) reveal whether the plant can set seed without its primary pollinator. If seed set drops to zero, the plant-side is obligate. If seed set is merely reduced, the relationship is facultative for the plant. (2) Offering the insect alternative food sources (other flower species with similar nectar/pollen) reveals whether it can survive and reproduce without the focal plant. If it cannot, the insect-side is obligate. Only if both partners fail without each other is the mutualism truly obligate (as in fig-fig wasp systems). Options A, C, and D provide useful information but do not directly test the obligate nature of the interaction.

questions.question:
Evaluate statements about pollen biology:
(I) The exine (outer wall) of pollen grains is composed of sporopollenin, one of the most resistant biological polymers known
(II) Pollen tube growth is guided by chemical signals from the synergid cells of the embryo sac
(III) All seed plants produce pollen grains with identical morphology
(IV) Self-incompatibility systems in many angiosperms involve recognition between pollen and stigma proteins encoded by the S-locus
Which are TRUE?
options: TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TTTF — I, II, and III are true
TFTT — I, III, and IV are true
TTTT — All are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: The exine is composed of sporopollenin, an extraordinarily resistant polymer of fatty acids and phenylpropanoids that withstands strong acids, bases, high temperatures, and enzymatic degradation. This resistance allows pollen to fossilize readily and makes palynology (pollen analysis) possible. Statement II is TRUE: In angiosperms, pollen tube growth through the style and into the embryo sac is guided by chemical attractants, particularly small peptides called LURE proteins secreted by synergid cells. These signals direct the pollen tube to the micropyle of the ovule. Statement III is FALSE: Pollen morphology varies enormously across seed plants—pollen grains differ in size (10-200 micrometers), shape, number of apertures, surface sculpture, and wall structure. These features are so species-specific that palynologists can identify plant species from pollen alone. Statement IV is TRUE: Self-incompatibility in many angiosperms involves the S-locus, where S-RNase (pistil) and S-locus F-box (pollen) proteins interact.

questions.question: In gymnosperms, the megagametophyte (female gametophyte) develops from:
options: a single functional megaspore retained within the megasporangium (nucellus)
a microspore that undergoes repeated mitotic divisions
the integument cells surrounding the ovule
the embryo sac derived from the endosperm
questions.explanation: In gymnosperms, the ovule contains a megasporangium (nucellus) in which a megaspore mother cell undergoes meiosis to produce four megaspores. Typically, three degenerate and one functional megaspore remains. This surviving megaspore undergoes repeated free-nuclear mitotic divisions (without cytokinesis initially) to produce a multicellular female gametophyte containing hundreds to thousands of cells. In conifers, this process takes about a year. Archegonia develop at the micropylar end of the female gametophyte. The female gametophyte remains enclosed within the nucellus and integument throughout its development—it is never free-living. This endosporic development within the retained megasporangium is a hallmark of seed plant reproduction.

questions.question: A conservation geneticist wants to assess the minimum viable population size for a rare gymnosperm species. Which combination of data is most essential?
options: Leaf morphology measurements and soil chemistry analysis
Fossil distribution data and historical range reconstructions
Pollen grain morphology and wood anatomy comparisons with related species
Effective population size estimates, genetic diversity metrics, inbreeding depression coefficients, and demographic vital rates
questions.explanation: Minimum viable population (MVP) analysis requires integrating genetic and demographic data. Essential components include: (1) Effective population size (Ne)—the genetically relevant population size, which is often much smaller than census size due to unequal sex ratios, variance in reproductive success, and population fluctuations. (2) Genetic diversity metrics (heterozygosity, allelic richness)—to assess the current genetic health and predict future diversity loss. (3) Inbreeding depression coefficients—to quantify how reduced heterozygosity affects fitness (survival, reproduction). (4) Demographic vital rates (birth, death, growth rates)—to model population persistence under various scenarios. Population viability analysis (PVA) integrates these data to estimate the minimum population size required to maintain 95% probability of persistence for a specified time period (typically 100 years). Options A, C, and D provide supplementary but not essential information for MVP estimation.

questions.question: In the pine life cycle, microsporangia are located:
options: within the ovulate (female) cone scales
on the microsporophylls of the pollen (male) cones
embedded in the bark of the main trunk
at the tips of needle-like leaves
questions.explanation: In pines and other conifers, microsporangia (pollen sacs) are located on the lower surface of microsporophylls, which are modified leaf-like structures arranged spirally to form male (pollen) cones (staminate strobili). Each microsporophyll typically bears two microsporangia. Within the microsporangia, microspore mother cells undergo meiosis to produce haploid microspores, which develop into pollen grains (male gametophytes). Male cones are typically smaller and more numerous than female cones, produced on lower branches, and shed vast quantities of wind-dispersed pollen. A single pine tree can produce billions of pollen grains in a season. The male cones are ephemeral, drying and falling from the tree after pollen release, unlike the persistent woody female cones that take 2-3 years to mature.

questions.question: The micropyle of the ovule serves as:
options: the site of meiosis producing megaspores
the opening through which the pollen tube enters to deliver sperm
the attachment point connecting the ovule to the placenta
the primary site of photosynthesis in the ovule
questions.explanation: The micropyle is a small pore or gap in the integument(s) at one end of the ovule. In gymnosperms, the micropyle is the opening where the pollination drop is secreted and through which pollen grains are drawn to the nucellus. In angiosperms, the pollen tube typically enters the ovule through the micropyle (porogamy) to deliver the two sperm cells to the embryo sac. After fertilization, the micropyle may be visible on the mature seed as a small pore or scar, sometimes serving as the point of water entry during seed imbibition prior to germination. The attachment point of the ovule is the funiculus (stalk), and its attachment scar on the seed is the hilum. The chalaza is the base of the ovule where the integuments and nucellus merge. Understanding ovule orientation (anatropous, orthotropous, campylotropous) requires knowing the relative positions of the micropyle, chalaza, hilum, and funiculus.

questions.question: The phenomenon of mast seeding in many tree species, where populations synchronously produce large seed crops at irregular intervals, is thought to function primarily by:
options: maximizing photosynthetic efficiency in years with optimal sunlight
synchronizing reproduction with migratory pollinator arrival
producing seeds only when soil nutrients peak after volcanic eruptions
overwhelming seed predators with more seeds than they can consume, ensuring some survive
questions.explanation: Mast seeding (masting) is a reproductive strategy in which tree populations across large areas synchronously produce enormous seed crops (mast years) interspersed with years of low or no seed production. The predator satiation hypothesis is the most strongly supported explanation: in mast years, the sheer volume of seeds overwhelms the consumption capacity of seed predators (squirrels, jays, rodents, insects), ensuring that many seeds escape predation and establish. In intervening low-seed years, predator populations decline due to food scarcity, so they cannot expand fast enough to consume the next mast crop. This strategy requires population-level synchrony, which may be cued by weather patterns (e.g., a warm spring followed by a cool period). Masting has significant ecosystem-wide effects, influencing predator populations, forest regeneration patterns, and even disease dynamics (e.g., Lyme disease through mouse population fluctuations).

questions.question: The pollination drop in gymnosperms functions to:
options: attract insect pollinators through its sugary composition
nourish the developing female gametophyte
prevent fungal infection of the ovule
capture wind-borne pollen grains and retract them toward the micropyle for germination
questions.explanation: The pollination drop is a secretion of sugary liquid produced at the micropyle of gymnosperm ovules during the receptive period. In wind-pollinated gymnosperms, airborne pollen grains land on this sticky droplet and become trapped. The pollination drop then retracts (through evaporation or active reabsorption), drawing the captured pollen grains through the micropyle and depositing them on the nucellus surface, where they can germinate and begin pollen tube growth. The pollination drop also provides moisture and nutrients that stimulate pollen germination. In some insect-pollinated gymnosperms (e.g., some cycads and Gnetales), the pollination drop may also serve as a reward for insect visitors, though this is secondary to its primary capture function. The biochemistry of the pollination drop is complex, containing sugars, amino acids, and proteins, some of which have antimicrobial properties.

questions.question: Amborella trichopoda, a shrub endemic to New Caledonia, is significant in angiosperm evolution because:
options: it is the only angiosperm that produces cones instead of flowers
molecular phylogenetics identifies it as the sister group to all other living angiosperms
it has the largest genome of any flowering plant
it demonstrates that angiosperms evolved in the Southern Hemisphere exclusively
questions.explanation: Amborella trichopoda is a small understory shrub endemic to the rainforests of New Caledonia in the South Pacific. Molecular phylogenetic analyses consistently place Amborella as the sole species in the earliest-diverging lineage of extant angiosperms—it is the sister group to all other living flowering plants. This makes Amborella critically important for understanding the ancestral features of angiosperms. It retains several apparently primitive features: small, simple flowers lacking petals, a single carpel with a single ovule, no vessel elements in its wood (only tracheids), and variable numbers of floral parts. However, being the sister group to all other angiosperms does not mean Amborella itself is ancestral—it has evolved for the same amount of time and has its own derived features. Its genome has been sequenced, providing crucial data for comparative angiosperm genomics.

questions.question: To investigate the role of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in attracting specific pollinators to flowers, which experimental design is most appropriate?
options: Observe which insects visit flowers of different colors in a garden
Present synthetic VOC blends matching different flower species to pollinators in a flight tunnel and record approach and landing behavior
Analyze the chemical composition of flower scents using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry
Compare pollinator visitation rates between scented and unscented flowers in the field
questions.explanation: A flight tunnel bioassay using synthetic VOC blends provides the most rigorous test of whether specific volatile compounds attract specific pollinators. This approach isolates the chemical (olfactory) signal from visual and other cues that confound field observations. By presenting synthetic blends that replicate the VOC profile of specific flower species—and systematically adding or removing individual compounds—the researcher can determine which specific chemicals or combinations are necessary and sufficient for pollinator attraction. Controls should include solvent-only blanks and mismatched species blends. Option A confounds scent with visual cues. Option C characterizes the signal but doesn't test its biological activity. Option D compares scented versus unscented but cannot identify which specific VOCs are responsible. The synthetic blend approach is standard in chemical ecology and has successfully identified key attractant compounds for many pollination systems.

questions.question: The evolution of animal-dispersed fleshy fruits in angiosperms illustrates the concept of:
options: parasitism, where plants exploit animals for their own benefit
mutualism, where plants provide nutrition (fruit flesh) in exchange for seed dispersal services
commensalism, where plants benefit but animals are unaffected
amensalism, where fruit consumption harms the animal consumer
questions.explanation: The relationship between fleshy-fruited plants and their animal dispersers is a classic example of mutualism. The plant invests resources in producing nutritious, attractive fruit tissue (sugars, lipids, vitamins, water) that serves as food for frugivorous animals. In return, animals carry seeds away from the parent plant—often to new, favorable sites for germination—in their digestive tracts or cached food stores. Many seeds actually require passage through an animal's gut for optimal germination, as digestive acids scarify the seed coat. This mutualism has driven extensive coevolution: fruits have evolved specific colors, sizes, nutritional profiles, and ripening signals that match their dispersers' sensory capabilities and dietary preferences. For example, bird-dispersed fruits tend to be red or black with high sugar content, while mammal-dispersed fruits tend to be dull-colored with strong odors.

questions.question:
About seed dormancy mechanisms:
(I) Physical dormancy involves a hard, impermeable seed coat that prevents water uptake
(II) Physiological dormancy involves internal chemical inhibitors that prevent germination
(III) All seeds require light for germination
(IV) Stratification (exposure to cold, moist conditions) breaks dormancy in many temperate species
Which are TRUE?
options: TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TFTF — I and III are true
TTTT — All are true
TFFT — I and IV are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: Physical dormancy (hardseededness) results from one or more water-impermeable layers in the seed coat or fruit wall, preventing water imbibition necessary for germination. Breaking physical dormancy requires scarification—mechanical abrasion, fire, or passage through an animal's digestive tract. Statement II is TRUE: Physiological dormancy involves chemical inhibitors (particularly abscisic acid, ABA) within the embryo or surrounding tissues that suppress germination until appropriate conditions reduce inhibitor levels or increase growth-promoting hormones (gibberellins). Statement III is FALSE: Light requirement for germination is species-specific. Some seeds require light (positively photoblastic), some require darkness (negatively photoblastic), and many are indifferent. Light requirement often correlates with seed size—small seeds near the soil surface benefit from light cues indicating favorable establishment conditions. Statement IV is TRUE: Many temperate species require stratification to break dormancy, ensuring germination occurs in spring rather than autumn.

questions.question: The seed ferns (Pteridosperms) are significant in plant evolution because they:
options: are living transitional forms between ferns and seed plants
were the earliest known seed plants, demonstrating that seeds evolved before the origin of cones or flowers
represent the direct ancestors of all modern ferns
were the first plants to evolve vascular tissue
questions.explanation: Seed ferns (Pteridosperms) were an extinct group of Paleozoic and Mesozoic plants that produced seeds on fern-like fronds, without cones or flowers. Despite their name, they are not true ferns—they are seed plants (spermatophytes). Their significance lies in demonstrating that seed reproduction evolved before the specialized reproductive structures (cones and flowers) found in modern gymnosperms and angiosperms. Seed ferns first appeared in the Late Devonian (~370 MYA), making them among the earliest known seed plants. Their fern-like foliage initially caused them to be classified as ferns until seeds were discovered attached to their fronds. Seed ferns are now extinct, but they document a crucial stage in reproductive evolution.
